Missouri Mule

And here I thought laughter was supposed to be good for one's health. I guess too much of a good thing is bad.
 =========================
 Thursday, June 09, 2005
 Man Reads Entire EU Constitution, Dies Of Laughter
 6/8/2005 - Matt Myford
 
 An Ohio man died yesterday after downloading the proposed European Union constitution off the internet and "reading the ghastly document in its entirety," according to state police in Columbus. The man died of "raging fits of laughter," police said. The man, whose identity is being withheld until his family is notified, is believed to be the first person to actually read the entire EU constitution. A leaked autopsy report said that human beings can "be subjected to only so many asininities" before "paralysis and even death can occur."...
 
 (Snip)
 
 Ohio state police issued a warning to "anyone considering reading this monstrosity, this ode to bureaucracy." Officials remarked that the constitution is "beyond satire-proof...a document so saturated with gobbledygook we can safely say it's the official text of the post-post-postmodern era."
 
 (Snip)
 
 "These EU elites can't write a constitution if their lives depended on it," said one U.S. political analyst. "But they're so damn funny - without even realizing it - they may be able to find work as writers on Letterman's show or something." 
 
 http://www.brokennewz.com/displaystory.asp_Q_storyid_E_1262euconst

By anyone's standards of satire that article isn't funny - the subject is beside the point, it's the execution that's flawed. As I pointed out earlier, it doesn't scan well. I say that because it doesn't read like a genuine american newspaper news item - it doesn't sound enough like, have the voice of, an actual news item.
 
 Like Obvious Child pointed out, the absurdity of the piece takes second stage to its politics and the humour suffers for it.

The combined economies of the EU are greater than the US. Europe does not suffer in terms of economic output because of being 'socialized': the Chinese economy is immensly powerful. And I'd rather live in a happy civilised country that supports its poor and vulnerable than make loads of money for its own sake or the sake of pride. There is nothing as sad as someone dedicated to money making who either has so much they can't spend it or doesn't really want to enjoy it anyway: the old 'Protestant work ethic' by which you slave all your life but ban almost all luxury.
